The rational design of non-noble metal catalysts for the highly efficient production of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) at mild reaction conditions is still a big challenge. In this work, the Co embedded in N-doped carbon as a robust catalyst is fabricated by in situ carbonizing ZIF-67 for the LA selective hydrogenation to GVL. Several catalysts that differed in pyrolysis temperatures, pyrolysis gas and preparation methods were prepared and evaluated. The optimal catalytic performance is achieved with Co@NC-800H, which realizes a up to 99% yield of GVL at low temperature of 120 °C and low hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa. Also, the optimal Co@NC-800H catalyst exhibits excellent reusability. By the careful characterizations with multiple techniques, including BET, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS and Raman, it is found that the excellent catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H is achieved through the synergistic catalysis between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZIF-67 Levulinic acid γ-valerolactone Oxygen vacancies Co-C x N y 1 Introduction The diminishing crude oil reserves and increasing environmental issues caused by the overspend of fossil feedstocks force scientists to find renewable substitutes. Hence, the utilization of renewable biomass feedstocks to produce liquid biofuels and fine chemicals has attracted increasing attentions [1,2]. Levulinic acid (LA), a vital platform chemical derived from the decomposition of renewable lignocellulose, can be used as a feedstock to produce abundance of sustainable chemicals with high added-value. For example, γ-valerolactone (GVL), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, 1,4-pentanediol, valeric acid and so on [2,3]. Among these valuable chemicals derived from LA, GVL is considered as one of the most promising derivatives obtained by the selective hydrogenation of LA, because it can be widely used as food additive, liquid fuel, green industrial solvent. Also, the GVL can act as renewable feedstocks to further produce other valuable derivatives [4,5]. Thus, the LA selective hydrogenation to GVL with high efficiency receives significant attentions. In the past decade, highly efficient synthesis of GVL via selective hydrogenation of LA has been achieved by the catalysis of precious metal catalysts under mild reaction conditions, e.g. Ru, Pd, Rh, Pt and Au [6–11]. However, the high cost and scarcity of noble metals obstruct their industrial application. Recently, various non-precious metal catalysts have been also developed to produce GVL through selective hydrogenation of LA [12–14]. For example, Hengne and Rode have explored the catalytic activity of Cu supported on various metal oxides (Cu/ZrO2, Cu/Al2O3, Cu/Cr2O3, Cu/BaO, Cu/Cr2O3-Al2O3, and Cu/BaO-Al2O3) [15]. The optimal Cu/ZrO2 catalyst finished complete LA conversion and 90% selectivity of GVL at 200 °C and 3.4 MPa H2. Hengst et al. successfully converted LA into GVL with a yield of 75% by using Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at 200 °C and 5 MPa H2 [16]. Co/Al2O3 catalyst derived from hydrotalcite was used to achieve a GVL yield up to 99% from LA hydrogenation at 180 °C and 5 MPa for 3 h [17]. In our recent study, a ternary catalyst of Cu/ZrO2-Al2O3 was designed to finish a high yield of GVL up to 99% at 130 °C and 3 MPa for 5 h [18]. Although the utilization of these catalysts free of precious metals also has been achieved high yield of GVL from selective hydrogenation of LA, the high yield of GVL relies on the harsh reaction conditions (high temperature and high pressure of H2). Hence, it is attractive to develop a robust catalyst for highly efficient production of GVL from LA under low temperature and H2 pressure. Nitrogen-doped carbon supported metal catalysts receives great attentions in recent years. The introducing nitrogen into the carbon architecture can stabilize the metal nanoparticles and favor the electron mobility, consequently enhancing the catalytic activity [19]. Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials have been applied as self-sacrificing templates to prepare highly dispersed metal catalysts for its ordered three-dimensional structures containing metal cation and organic ligand with high surface area and adjustable porosity [20]. The pyrolysis of MOF usually generates highly dispersed metal nanoparticles embedded in porous carbon matrix, because the porous carbon materials can effectively anchor the metal particles and prevent it aggregation [20,21]. Zhao et al. fabricated N-doped Co catalyst via the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 for the CO2 methanation reaction, which gave a 48.5% CO2 conversion with the 97.1% selectivity to CH4 [21]. The Fe-based catalysts obtained by the pyrolysis of Fe-MIL-88B achieved a 46.0% conversion of CO2 for CO2 methanation reaction [22]. Of these MOF materials, ZIF-67 can be facilely fabricated with low cost. Also, it contains abundant N species and thus avoid the addition of external N species. Herein, the Co embedded in N-doped carbon as a robust catalyst is fabricated by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 for the LA selective hydrogenation to GVL. The obtained catalyst Co@NC-800H achieves a up to 99% yield of GVL at low temperature of 120 °C and low hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa. Based on the systemic characterizations, the synergistic catalysis between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y sites is accounted for the excellent performance of Co@NC-800H. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZIF-67 was synthesized as follows: 3.49 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 3.94 g 2-methylimidazole were respectively dissolved by 60 mL methanol. Then the 2-methylimidazole solution was quickly added into the solution of Co(NO3)2, following by stirring for 20 h at room temperature. The ZIF-67 solid was obtained by centrifugation, washing four times with ethanol and drying at 60 °C in air for 24 h. The as-synthesized ZIF-67 was firstly heated in a flow of 10% H2/Ar to 400 ℃ for 2 h, and then to the designed temperature for 1 h with a heating rate of 2 ℃/min. The obtained samples were denoted as Co@NC-xH (x represents the final pyrolysis temperature, e.g. 500, 600, 700, 800, and 900). Besides, Co@NC-800N catalyst was also obtained by the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 particles at 800 °C in a flow of N2. Co@NC-800NH catalyst was obtained by the pyrolysis of Co@NC-800N in the flow of 10% H2/Ar at 800 °C for 1 h. The NC without of metal cobalt was prepared as below: briefly, 0.6 g Co@NC-800H was added into a flask with 120 mL 6 M HNO3 aqueous solution. After refluxing for 6 h at 120 °C, the black solid was obtained by centrifugation, washing several times with distilled water and ethanol and drying at 60 °C in air for 24 h. The obtained product was denoted as NC. The Co/NC and Co/AC catalysts were prepared via a wet impregnation. For Co/NC, 200 mg NC was added into 1.6 mL of 1.89 mol/L Co(NO3)2 aqueous solution under ultrasonication. After vigorous ultrasonic treatment for 2 h at room temperature, the mixture was evaporated at 80 °C and dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h. Then the obtained sample was reduced at 500 °C for 2 h under 10% H2/Ar flow. The Co/AC catalyst was prepared with the same method by using commercial active carbon as support. 2.2 Characterizations The surface area and porosity of the catalysts were measured on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88 via N2 physisorption experiments at -196 °C. All catalysts were degassed at 350 °C under vacuum for 300 min before analysis. The Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation was used to conduct the X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. The contents of Co of different catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Prodigy 7, Leeman Labs, USA). The morphology and microstructure of sample were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Hitachi SU-8020, Japan). Transmission electron microscopes (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDX) images were obtained on JEM-2100F (JEOL, Japan) with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Raman spectra of the samples were performed on a Renishaw inVia Reflex Raman Spectroscope using an IK series He-Cd laser operating at 532 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on the X-ray photoelectron spectrometer system (ESCALAB Xi+, USA) from Thermo Fisher Scientific. The temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried out on an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA). For NH3-TPD tests, 50 mg sample was placed in a quartz tube reactor and pretreated in He at 300 °C for 120 min. The treated sample was saturated with 10% NH3/He for 60 min and then purged with He for 30 min at 100 °C. Finally, the sample was heated to 800 °C with a rate of 10°C/min. The H2-TPD studies were carried out to estimate the dispersion of cobalt. The study method is the same as NH3-TPD except that 10% NH3/He is replaced by 10% H2/Ar and He is replaced by Ar as the atmosphere of treatment. The detailed calculation methods of cobalt dispersion according to literature [21]. For the H2-TPR, the sample (30 mg) was pretreated in Ar at 80 °C for 30 min and then heated to 900 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of 10% H2/Ar after being cooled down to 40 °C. 2.3 Catalytic tests The performance tests of these catalysts were carried out in an autoclave (35 mL). Typically, 80 mg LA, 20 mL solvent and 20 mg catalyst were introduced into the autoclave. After being purged three times with N2 flow, the autoclave was charged with H2 to the desired pressure. Afterwards, the autoclave was heated to target temperature for reaction. After the reaction, the autoclave was quickly cooled to room temperature in an ice-water. The reaction liquids were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography. The LA conversion was calculated via the equation as following: C LA ( % ) = moles of conv erted LA moles of init ial LA × 100 The GVL yield was calculated by the equation as following: Y GVL ( % ) = moles of prod uct GVL moles of init ial LA × 100 The GVL selectivity was calculated by the equation as following: S GVL ( % ) = moles of prod uct GVL moles of conv erted LA × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance and characterization The catalytic performances of the various catalysts for the LA hydrogenation to GVL were evaluated at 110 °C under 3 MPa H2 for 3 h, the results are listed in Table 1 . Evidently, the pyrolysis temperature significantly influenced the catalytic activity of the catalysts derived from ZIF-67. The Co@NC-500H, which was obtained by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 at 500 °C in a 10% H2/Ar flow, achieves a low LA conversion of 44.9% (Enry 1 of Table 1). Under identical reaction conditions, the LA conversion and GVL yield increase remarkably as the pyrolysis temperature inclines (Entry 1–4 of Table 1), Co@NC-800H reaches the highest LA conversion of 92.1% with the GVL selectivity up to 99% (Entry 4 of Table 1). When the pyrolysis temperature further inclines up to 900 °C, the catalytic activity slightly decreases (Entry 5 of Table 1). The catalytic activity is also controlled by the types of pyrolysis gas. The catalyst (Co@NC-800N) obtained by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 in an inert gas flow of N2 only gives inferior catalytic activity with a low LA conversion of 26.8% (Entry 6 of Table 1), which is much lower than that of Co@NC-800H. After the secondary pyrolysis of Co@NC-800N in 10% H2/Ar flow, the catalytic activity recovers notably (Entry 7 of Table 1), although it is also lower than that of Co@NC-800H. When metal cobalt in Co@NC-800H was washed away by nitric acid solution, the sole NC catalyst is almost inactive for the hydrogenation of LA (Entry 8 of Table 1), suggesting that the metal cobalt is important to maintain the catalytic activity. However, even though equivalent weight of metal cobalt was introduced in sole NC by immersion, the Co/NC exhibits inferior catalytic activity than Co@NC-800H (Entry 9 of Table 1). Besides, the Co/AC catalyst with equivalent weight of metal cobalt supported on activated carbon shows an extremely poor activity for the hydrogenation of LA (Entry 10 of Table 1), probably due to the absence of nitrogen heteroatom doping on carbon matrix. As stated above, the Co@NC-800H displays excellent catalytic performance for the LA hydrogenation to produce GVL at low temperature. Hence, detailed characterizations of this sample were carried out and compared to those of other samples. Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the various catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Co@NC-500H mainly presents weak peaks belonged to Co3O4, the absence of diffraction peaks for metallic cobalt evidences that cobalt oxide species are not well reduced at the low pyrolysis temperature of 500 °C. In the case of Co@NC-600H, the diffraction peaks of metallic cobalt emerge. As the pyrolysis temperature further increases, the diffraction peaks of metallic cobalt become clear and intensive. The XRD patterns displayed in Fig. 1b indicate that the cobalt oxide species in all these samples obtained via different methods are reduced into metallic cobalt. But the average size of cobalt particles, calculated based on Scherrer formula, is in obvious difference (Column 5 of Table 2 ). The cobalt particle size of these catalysts derived from ZIF-67 is much smaller than those of Co/NC and Co/AC. The cobalt particle size obtained by TEM in the later section further confirms this result. The Co@NC-800H has the smallest cobalt particles among these catalysts. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted to investigate the texture properties of these samples prepared by different methods. As displayed in Fig. S1, these samples possess I and IV adsorption-desorption isotherm, suggesting their microporous and mesoporous structure, which is also confirmed by their pore size distribution (Fig. S1b). The morphology and microstructure of Co@NC-800H were elucidated by SEM and TEM characterizations (Fig. 2 ). As displayed in Fig. 2a, the SEM images clearly show that the as-prepared ZIF-67 presents uniform dodecahedral structure. Upon pyrolysis in the flow of 10% H2/Ar at 800 °C, the dodecahedral structure is almost well maintained (Fig. 2b), but its surface becomes rough. The newborn carbon nanotubes can be observed clearly on the surface of Co@NC-800H (Fig. 2c), also a part of cobalt nanoparticles with an average particle size of 13.1 nm are confined in these nanotubes (Fig. 2c–g). Besides, the nitrogen element is homogeneously distributed over carbon matrix (Fig. 2h). In contrast, these samples obtained by pyrolysis in the flow of inert gas N2 present smooth surface without the formation of carbon nanotubes (Fig. S2a,b). These samples derived from ZIF-67 (Co@NC-800H, Co@NC-800N and Co@NC-800NH) possess small cobalt particle size in the range of 13∼16 nm, probably due to that the carbon matrix derived from ZIF-67 can anchor cobalt particles and in turn prevent sintering [21]. In contrast, the cobalt particles over the Co/NC and Co/AC catalysts prepared by impregnation are aggregated obviously (Fig. S2). The difference of particle size of cobalt particles observed in TEM is consistent with that detected by XRD. XPS characterizations were conducted to determine the surface composition and chemical states of the catalysts prepared by different methods. The XPS surveys (Fig. S3) suggest that these samples (Co@NC-800H, Co@NC-800N, Co@NC-800NH and Co/NC) contain Co, C, N and O elements. As listed in Table S1, the relatively lower contents of N element detected over Co@NC-800H, implying that the pyrolysis with 10% H2/Ar decreases the contents of N element. The C 1s spectra can be well deconvoluted into several peaks, assigning to C-C/N, C-O, O-C=O and sp2 carbon (Fig. 3 a) [23]. The contents of sp2 carbon is an indicator of the degree of graphitization [23]. As shown in column 1 of Table 3 , the Co@NC-800H contains the highest contents of sp2 carbon among these catalysts, indicating its high degree of graphitization. As illustrated in Fig. 3b, the O 1s peaks of these catalysts can be decomposed to two distinct peaks, belonging to surface oxygen vacancies and adsorption oxygen, respectively [19,24]. A lot of oxygen vacancies are determined over the surface of these samples derived via in situ carburization of ZIF-67 (Column 9 of Table 3, Co@NC-800H, Co@NC-800N and Co@NC-800NH). These surface oxygen vacancies are beneficial for the adsorption of LA [18]. The N 1s spectra of these samples can be carefully separated into graphitic-N, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N (Fig. 3c) [21,25]. The Co@NC-800N derived via pyrolysis in inert gas N2 contains a low content of graphitic-N and relatively high content of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N. After the secondary pyrolysis in 10% H2/Ar, the content of graphitic-N increases to 32.9% over Co@NC-800NH. The highest contents of graphitic-N are obtained over Co@NC-800H. These results imply that the H2 presenting in the pyrolysis gas can enhance the transformation of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N into graphitic-N. Fig. 3d displays the Co 2p spectra, the Co 2p spectra present three peaks at about 778.7 eV, 780.3 eV and 782.3 eV, which are belonged to Coo, Co-C x N y and Co-N x species, respectively [26,27]. As listed in Table 3, the Co@NC-800N possesses 64.0% of Co-N x species, but low contents of Coo and Co-C x N y species. In contrast, the lowest amounts of Co-Nx species, but the highest contents of Coo and Co-C x N y species are obtained over Co@NC-800H. The high contents of Co-C x N y species over Co@NC-800H may result from its large amount of sp2 carbon and graphitic-N, which could favor the formation of Co-C x N y species. Fig. S4 illustrates the Raman spectra of these samples prepared via different methods. For all these samples, two dominant bands located at around 1350 cm−1 and 1580 cm−1, which belonged to defective (D) carbon and graphitic (G) carbon respectively, can be observed. The intensity ratio of the D band to G band (ID/IG) reflected the degree of graphitization [25]. The value of ID/IG for Co@NC-800N is 0.65. After the secondary pyrolysis with 10% H2/Ar, the value of ID/IG for Co@NC-800NH decreases, suggesting the increasing degree of graphitization. Furthermore, the Co@NC-800H exhibits the lowest value of ID/IG among these samples. These results imply that the pyrolysis with H2 improves the graphitization degree, which is consistent with the results of XPS. The enhanced graphitization can favor the electronic mobility. The low catalytic activity of Co@NC-500H is due to its lack of activity metal cobalt. The poor catalytic performance of sole NC evidences also confirms that metal cobalt is essential for the hydrogenation of LA, while the inferior activity of Co/AC implies that physicochemical property of carbon support or the interaction between cobalt and N-doped carbon support is also vital. The Co-N x sites have been reported to be the active sites for the selective hydrogenation reactions [25]. In our results, the Co@NC-800N possesses the highest contents of Co-N x species as evidenced by the XPS results, but it only gives a low LA conversion of 26.8%. Thus, it is probably that the Co-N x species is not the highest active sites for the hydrogenation of LA in the present study. As the Co@NC-800NH was treated by the secondary pyrolysis in a flow of 10% H2/Ar, the catalytic activity is improved notably. As revealed by the results of XPS and Raman, the graphitization of carbon matrix and graphitic-N increases apparently after secondary pyrolysis in 10% H2/Ar. The enhanced graphitization carbon matrix and increasing graphitic-N would favor the electronic mobility, probably facilitating the interaction among Co, C and N species. Zhao et al. proposed that the existence of H2 in the pyrolysis gas enhances the electron transfer between Co and carbon matrix [21]. Hence, the pyrolysis in 10% H2/Ar may facilitates the electron transformation among Co, C and N species, probably favors the formation of Co-C x N y species. Compared to Co@NC-800N, an increasing content of Co-C x N y species is observed for Co@NC-800NH as determined by the results of XPS results. Also, as revealed by results of element mapping of Co@NC-800H (Fig. 2h), N element is homogeneously distributed in carbon matrix. The homogeneous distribution of N element suggests the intimate interaction of N with C species. The intimate interaction between N and C would facilitate the formation of Co-C x N y species. Furthermore, when the ZIF-67 precursor was treated in the flow of 10% H2/Ar, the highest amount of Co-C x N y species is obtained for Co@NC-800H. The H2-TPR of Co@NC-800H presents an obvious peak at low temperature at around 200 °C (Fig. S5), which may be corresponded to the dissociative adsorption of H2 over the Co-CxNy sites. Thus, these Co-CxNy species may play important roles on the dissociative adsorption of H2. Also, abundance of oxygen vacancies is detected over Co@NC-800H. As revealed in our previous work [18], these oxygen vacancies favor the adsorption and activation of LA. Hence, with the synergistic catalytic effect between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y , the Co@NC-800H presents an excellent catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of LA. In general, the reaction network for the yield of GVL from LA hydrogenation undergoes one of the following two reaction pathways: (1) first hydrogenation of the ketone group of LA to form intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid (HPA), followed by its dehydration and cyclization and subsequent production of GVL, and (2) initial dehydration of LA to α-angelica lactone followed by its hydrogenation to GVL. The former pathway of GVL production is thermodynamically preferred and demonstrated to be the dominant route at low temperature, especially in liquid-phase hydrogenation [13,18,28]. Also, the intermediate angelica lactone is undetected in our reaction conditions, as displayed in Fig. S6. The absence of intermediate angelic lactone indicated that the hydrogenation of LA may undergoes the pathway with 4-hydroxypentanoic acid as reaction intermediate. Based on our experimental results and previous studies in literatures [13,18,28], the possible reaction route is proposed in Scheme 1. The LA will be firstly adsorbed and activated on these surface oxygen vacancies, and then undergoes the hydrodeoxygenation over Co-C x N y sites to form intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoic acid. The 4-hydroxypentanoic acid will undergo dehydration and cyclization catalyzed by acid sites to produce the desired product of GVL. In our work, the amount of acid sites is not directly correlated with the catalytic performance for these catalysts. As listed in the column 8 of Table 2, among these catalysts, the Co/NC and Co/AC catalysts have more acid sites than Co@NC-800H, but their catalytic activity is worse than Co@NC-800H. Perhaps the dehydration and cyclization steps catalyzed by acid sites are not the rate-determining step over these catalysts used in our work. The catalytic activity of these catalysts in our work may be mainly controlled by the adsorption and activation of LA catalyzed by the synergy of Co-CxNy species and oxygen vacancy. Therefore, the excellent catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H is realized via the synergistic effect between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y . 3.2 Optimization of the reaction conditions The influences of reaction conditions (H2 pressure, reaction temperature and catalyst loading) on catalytic performance were investigated over Co@NC-800H, the results are presented in Fig. 4 . The effect of H2 pressure was conducted at low temperature of 120 °C for 3 h by varying the H2 pressure in the range of 0.5∼3.0 MPa. As shown in Fig. 4a, the H2 pressure significantly influences the catalytic activity. When the reaction was carried out at low H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa, 41.5% of LA conversion is obtained. The increasing H2 pressure sharply improves the catalytic activity. As the H2 pressure increases to 2.0 MPa, the LA is completely converted, the yield of GVL reaches up to 99%. The further increase of H2 pressure almost not affects the catalytic performance. In the practical application, the harsh reaction condition of high H2 pressure will remarkably raise production costs and increase operating dangers. Hence, we try to explore the catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H at low H2 pressure. When the H2 pressure is fixed at 0.5 MPa, as expected, the elevating reaction temperature obviously increases the conversion of LA (Fig. 4b). More importantly, as illustrated in Fig. 4c, a high yield of GVL up to 99% is achieved over Co@NC-800H at low temperature of 120 °C and low H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa through appropriately adjusting the catalyst loading. From the literature survey, compared the catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H to those reported in previous literatures, as summarized in Table 4 , it is clearly demonstrated that the Co@NC-800H possesses better performance than other non-noble metal catalysts when the catalysts were evaluated under comparable severe reaction condition. 3.3 Catalyst recyclability The reusability of Co@NC-800H was also evaluated. The used catalyst was recovered by centrifugation after each run, washed several times with solvent, dried at 70 °C in a vacuum oven, and then reused in the next run. The recycled experiments were firstly carried out by using deionized water as solvent. As illustrated in in Fig. S7, the catalytic activity decreases notably after each recycle. As mentioned in the experimental section, the cobalt particles in Co@NC-800H can be washed off by nitric acid solution. The substrate of LA solution is also an acidic solution. This acidic LA solution cause the leaching of cobalt metal during the reaction, which is evidenced by the fact that large amounts of cobalt was detected via the analysis of the reaction solution after reaction (Table S2). Thus, the leaching of cobalt leads to the deactivation for the loss of active cobalt metal. However, when the reused experiments were conducted by using 1,4-dioxane as solvent, as shown in Fig. 5 , Co@NC-800H exhibits excellent reusability, a high catalytic performance can maintain for 5 recycled times. This is probably due to the fact that the leaching of cobalt is avoided in the organic solvent. 4 Conclusions In this work, the Co embedded in N-doped carbon as a robust catalyst is designed by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 in 10% H2/Ar flow for the selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The optimal catalyst Co@NC-800H achieves excellent catalytic performance with a yield of GVL up to 99% under mild reaction conditions (120 °C and 0.5 MPa H2). Also, the optimal Co@NC-800H catalyst exhibits excellent reusability. The excellent catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H is achieved through the synergistic catalysis between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y sites. coredata.dc:description: The rational design of non-noble metal catalysts for the highly efficient production of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) at mild reaction conditions is still a big challenge. In this work, the Co embedded in N-doped carbon as a robust catalyst is fabricated by in situ carbonizing ZIF-67 for the LA selective hydrogenation to GVL. Several catalysts that differed in pyrolysis temperatures, pyrolysis gas and preparation methods were prepared and evaluated. The optimal catalytic performance is achieved with Co@NC-800H, which realizes a up to 99% yield of GVL at low temperature of 120 °C and low hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa. Also, the optimal Co@NC-800H catalyst exhibits excellent reusability. By the careful characterizations with multiple techniques, including BET, XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS and Raman, it is found that the excellent catalytic performance of Co@NC-800H is achieved through the synergistic catalysis between oxygen vacancies and Co-C x N y sites.
coredata.dc:title: Co-C x N y embedded in N-doped carbon as robust catalysts for the synthesis of γ-valerolactone from the hydrogenation of levulinic acid under low hydrogen pressure
